entry.content:
Digital Home

I was given this machine for free because it had a bad power supply. I took apart the power supply but all I found was a loose screw. I put it back together and the power supply seems to work fine.

When I first got the machine, I could not enter the ARC firmware console. When I entered "arc" at the SRM console, the console would say "ARC firmware loaded" and freeze. I found a post on vogons that described a similar problem on an alphastation. Doing the same repair on the Dallas DS1287 TOY NVRAM fixed my issue.

So far I have OpenVMS 8.4 installed on the system. I plan on installing Windows NT, Windows 2000, and NetBSD on the different hard disks that the system came with.

entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

The chassis is a cheap metal project box that you can find all over Amazon or eBay. I liked it because the color reminded me of an Altair 8800. I 3D printed some parts to help hold the PSU (from an old Dell PC) and the disk drives. The backplane is sandwiched in between two 3D printed pieces. Bolts come up through the bottom of the chassis through the  guide rails for the PCBs to hold the entire assembly together. I'm not happy with this design. Eventually I want to get a larger backplane so I can install more cards. Right now, I can't fit everything at the same time.

The backplane is just a 40 row strip board with pin headers soldered on it.

entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

Currently this board is very simple because only the IDE part is implemented. Eventually, a floppy controller will be added to this board. 
The hard disk is connected directly to the Z80's bus. I'm considering re-making this board and adding bus transceivers for both the IDE disk and the FDD controller. So far, I've only found 1 model of hard disk that works with this setup, and I'm assuming its because there's no bus transceiver. Only 8 bits of the 16 bit data bus on the hard disk is used. The other top 8 are pulled to ground. The only chip on the board is a 3 to 8 demux for address decoding.

entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

I wanted to try out wire wrap, but I didn't have enough space on the back of the board, or any wire wrap sockets. So, I soldered pin headers on either side of the ICs and wire wrapped on the top of the board. Its not the nicest looking wire wrap, but I'm happy with how it came out. It's also easy than doing point to point soldering in my opinion. 

I don't have an application yet, but eventually I'd like to write a clock program to write to my VFD Board I designed. I was going to read the time from an i2C clock chip by bit banging with the PIO.
